# Field Effect Transistors (FET)

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_1.gif)

__The Field effect transistors \(FETs\) __ are  <span style="color:#ff0000">unipolar devices</span>  because\, unlike BJTs that use both electron and hole current\, they operate only with one type of charge carrier\.

Therefore\, FET is a unipolar device that depends on only one type of charge carrier\, either  free electrons or holes\.

<span style="color:#0000ff">FET </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">is </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">a </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">three\-terminal </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">device </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">similar </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">to </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">the </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">bipolar  </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">junction</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> transistor</span> \.

There are basically two types of FETs:

<span style="color:#0000ff">Junction </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">field </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">effect </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">transistor\,</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> __JFET__ </span>  <span style="color:#336600">\.</span>

<span style="color:#0000ff">M</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">etal\-oxide\-semiconductor </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">field </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">effect </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">transistor\,</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> __MOSFET__ </span>  <span style="color:#336600">\.</span>

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_2.gif)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_3.png)

Recall that a  <span style="color:#ff0000">BJT</span>  is a current\-controlled device; that is\,  <span style="color:#336600">the base current controls the amount of collector current</span> \.

<span style="color:#0000ff">A </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">FET</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> is a voltage\-controlled device\, where the </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _voltage between two of the terminals \(gate and source\) controls the current through the device_ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">\.</span>

A major advantage of  <span style="color:#ff0000">FETs</span>  is their very high input resistance\.

The three terminals are the:

<span style="color:#ff0000">\- Gate\.</span>

<span style="color:#ff0000">	\- Drain\.</span>

<span style="color:#ff0000">	\- Source\.</span>

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_4.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_5.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">Because of their </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> __nonlinear characteristics__ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">\, they are generally </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> _not as widely used in amplifiers _ </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">as BJTs except where very high input impedances are required\. </span>

FETs are the preferred device in low\-voltage switching applications\,  <span style="color:#ff0000"> __Why?__ </span>

Because they can perform fast switching\, faster than BJTs when turned on and off\.

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_6.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#ff0000">FETs</span>  are more temperature stable than  <span style="color:#ff0000">BJTs</span> \.

<span style="color:#ff0000">FETs</span>  are usually smaller than  <span style="color:#ff0000">BJTs</span> \, making them particularly useful in integrated\-circuit \(IC\) chips\.

<span style="color:#008000">The input impedance is extremely high \(Megohms\) for FETs\, so they require very little power from the driving source\.</span>

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_7.jpg)

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_8.jpg)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#ff0000">Junction Field Effect Transistor\- JFET</span>

The  <span style="color:#ff0000"> __JFET__ </span>  \(junction field\-effect transistor\) is a type of FET that operates with a  reverse\-biased pn junction to control current in a channel\.

<span style="color:#0000ff">Depending on their structure\, JFETs fall into either of two categories</span> \-

<span style="color:#008000">            \- n channel\, called </span> n\-channel JFET\.

<span style="color:#008000">            \- p channel\, </span>  <span style="color:#008000">called </span> p\-channel JFET\.

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_10.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#ff0000">JFET\- Schematics</span>

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_11.png)

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_12.png)

The only difference is the direction of the arrow on the gate lead\.

The arrow points in toward the n \-type channel\, whereas the arrow points outward from the p\- type channel\.

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_13.png)

BJTs are  current controlled devices\,

<span style="color:#0000ff">FETs are voltage­ controlled devices</span> \, \(i\.e\. an input voltage controls an output current\)\.

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_14.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

The amount of current flow \(for a fixed value of VGS\) depends upon two factors:

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_15.png)

<span style="color:#336600"> __The value of the drain\-source voltage\, V__ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> __DS__ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> __ __ </span>

<span style="color:#336600"> __The drain\-source resistance\, designated __ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> __r__ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> __ds__ </span>  <span style="color:#336600"> __·__ </span>

The value of rds is dependent on the  _doping level_ \,  _cross ­sectional area_ \, and  _length of the doped semiconductor material _ used for the channel\.

<span style="color:#0000ff">In a JFET\, the source current\, I</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">S </span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">\, and the drain current\, I</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">D</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff"> are the same\. </span>

In most cases\, therefore\, the current flow is considered to be only the drain current\, ID\.

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#ff0000">JFET\- Basic Operation</span>



* DC bias voltages applied to an n\-channel device:
  * <span style="color:#0000ff">V</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">DD</span>  provides a drain\-to\-source voltage and supplies current from drain to source\.
  * <span style="color:#0000ff">V</span>  <span style="color:#0000ff">GG</span>  sets the reverse\-bias voltage between the gate and the source\.
* <span style="color:#ff0000">JFET is always operated with the </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _gate\-source _ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _pn_ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _ junction reverse\-biased_ </span>  <span style="color:#ff0000">\. </span>


![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_16.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#ff0000">JFET\- Basic Operation</span>

<span style="color:#336600">Reverse\-biasing of the gate\-source junction produces a depletion region along the </span>  <span style="color:#336600">pn</span>  <span style="color:#336600"> junction\, which extends into the channel\.</span>

<span style="color:#c00000">It increases its resistance by restricting the channel width\.</span>

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_17.png)

Therefore\, the  <span style="color:#336600">channel width </span> and thus the  <span style="color:#336600">channel resistance </span> can be controlled by varying the gate voltage\, thereby controlling the amount of drain current\, ID\.

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

<span style="color:#7030a0">Case when the gate\-to\-source voltage is zero \(V</span>  <span style="color:#7030a0">GS</span>  <span style="color:#7030a0"> = 0 V\)\.</span>

Increasing VDD \(and thus VDS\) from 0V\, ID will increase proportionally\, between points A and B\.

<span style="color:#336600"> __Ohmic Region:  __ </span> In this area\, the channel resistance is essentially constant because the depletion region is not large enough to have significant effect\.

In ohmic region VDS and ID are related by Ohm’s law\.

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_25.png)

<span style="color:#ff0000">JFET\- Characteristics and Parameters</span>

<span style="color:#7030a0">Case when the gate\-to\-source voltage is zero \(V</span>  <span style="color:#7030a0">GS</span>  <span style="color:#7030a0"> = 0 V\)\.</span>

<span style="color:#0000ff">Breakdown </span> occurs at point C when ID begins to increase very rapidly with any further increase in VDS\.

<span style="color:#ff0000">Breakdown can result in irreversible damage to the device\, so JFETs are always operated below breakdown and within the active region \(constant current\) \(between points B and C on the graph\)\. </span>

<span style="color:#ff0000">MOSFET \- Basic Operation</span>

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_31.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">MOSFETs can operate in two modes:</span>

<span style="color:#0000ff">Depletion mode </span>  <span style="color:#336600">\(like the JFET\)\, where the ability to pass current can be reduced or increased\.</span>

The channel exists between the source and drain and allows a current to flow IDSS even when VGS = 0V\.

<span style="color:#0000ff">Enhancement mode</span>  <span style="color:#336600">\, where the ability to pass current is increased\.</span>

For current to flow channel need to be created by applying gate voltage above a threshold voltage VGS\(th\)\.

![](l5.1-fets-img/l51-fets_32.png)

<span style="color:#0000ff">The only difference between n\- and p\-channel devices is that the supply voltage used for p\-channel devices is of the opposite polarity from that used for n\-channel devices\.</span>
